user.text: why MacArthur didn't criminalize the Emperor that time?

agent.speaker: agent
agent.text: General Douglas MacArthur did not hold Emperor Hirohito responsible for war crimes because he believed that the continuation of the imperial institution was necessary for the stability and rehabilitation of Japan.  At a meeting with the General later in September aboard the Missouri, Emperor Hirohito offered to take blame for the war crimes, but his offer was rejected, and he was never tried. As the Allied seemed to leave intact the principle of the preservation of the Throne , the Declaration made no mention of the Emperor at all . Allied intentions on issues of utmost importance to the Japanese, including whether Hirohito was to be regarded as one of those who had misled the people of Japan '' or even a war criminal, or alternatively, whether the Emperor might become part of a peacefully inclined and responsible government '' were thus left unstated.

contexts.text:
Surrender of Japan
After the formal surrender on September 2 aboard Missouri , investigations into Japanese war crimes began quickly . At a meeting with General MacArthur later in September , Emperor Hirohito offered to take blame for the war crimes , but his offer was rejected , and he was never tried . Legal procedures for the International Military Tribunal for the Far East were issued on January 19 , 1946 .
contexts.title: Surrender of Japan

contexts.text:
Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
On August 12 , the Emperor informed the imperial family of his decision to surrender . One of his uncles , Prince Asaka , then asked whether the war would be continued if the kokutai could not be preserved . Hirohito simply replied , `` Of course . '' As the Allied terms seemed to leave intact the principle of the preservation of the Throne , Hirohito recorded on August 14 his capitulation announcement which was broadcast to the Japanese nation the next day despite a short rebellion by militarists opposed to the surrender .
contexts.title: Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki

contexts.text:
Surrender of Japan
Contrary to what had been intended at its conception , the Declaration made no mention of the Emperor at all . Allied intentions on issues of utmost importance to the Japanese , including whether Hirohito was to be regarded as one of those who had `` misled the people of Japan '' or even a war criminal , or alternatively , whether the Emperor might become part of a `` peacefully inclined and responsible government '' were thus left unstated .
contexts.title: Surrender of Japan

agent.original_text: General Douglas MacArthur did not hold Emperor Hirohito responsible for war crimes because he believed that the continuation of the imperial institution was necessary for the stability and rehabilitation of Japan. MacArthur saw the Emperor as a symbol of unity and a figurehead who could help in implementing the necessary changes in Japan's political and social structure. Moreover, Hirohito's role in the war was seen as more ceremonial and less directly involved in the military atrocities committed by Japan. Therefore, MacArthur decided not to pursue criminal charges against the Emperor, and instead focused on the prosecution of other high-ranking Japanese officials responsible for war crimes.

llm_based_tags.reasoning: The phrase 'that time' is a temporal anaphoric expression requiring context to identify which specific historical period is being referenced. While the query mentions MacArthur and the Emperor (likely referring to Emperor Hirohito of Japan), 'that time' creates ambiguity about whether this refers to post-WWII occupation, a specific year, or another historical moment. The query is grammatically complete but semantically requires prior context to fully understand the temporal reference.
